Hi Wesley, when I referred to social learning in society I was more looki=
ng at the implication in the opposite direction:  It does appear as you poi=
nt out that human social transmission and learning benefits novelty in huma=
n society.  But what does that mean for algorithms that do not work on huma=
n-level intelligences?   Can an abstract social-learning algorithm exhibit =
the same benefits, or will it tend more towards convergence because of the =
rapid proliferation of the highest-fitness "wisdom" throughout society?

ke=
n

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ke=
n,
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> We did actually try leveraging the species created by =
NEAT, but
> unfortunately that wasn't useful for two reasons. First, the di=
stribution
> of the population was heavily lopsided. We had a population of=
 100 genomes
> and 10 species, but the size of species 0 was usually around=
 80 genomes.
> Second, even accounting for this, we saw better performance =
from randomly
> selecting individuals for subcultures.
> 
> This makes intu=
itive sense to me, since speciation is intended for the
> opposite of what =
subcultures should be doing. Speciation is aimed at
> grouping similar indi=
viduals in genome space, thereby protecting (with the
> help of fitness sha=
ring) innovation in the population and allowing it to
> flourish. Subcultur=
es, however, are intended to create diverse groups of
> individuals in phen=
ome space and thus promote the sharing of innovations
> among the populatio=
n. In this light, I think it's clear why randomly
> composed subcultures wo=
uld outperform species-based: individuals in the
> same species, with simil=
ar genomes, are more likely to have similar
> phenotypic behavior and obser=
vations of similar individuals really won't
> help social agents outside of=
 some minor local optimization on the
> sub-policies they have already disc=
overed.
> 
> Philosophically, I think the results are actually very encoura=
ging when
> applied to human society. We show that the notion of learning o=
nly from
> what those in power tell you is actually a suboptimal strategy. =
Rather,
> everyone-- rich, poor, young, old, etc-- may have something to co=
ntribute
> and even if overall they aren't as "fit" as everyone else, their=
 individual
> actions can still have worth and add value to society.
> 
> S=
pecifically to novelty, I believe social transmission is crucial in human
>=
 societies. Generally when biologists study learning paradigms in nature,
>=
 there are a few levels of cognitive ability. In our experiments we were
> =
effectively applying  an emulation paradigm, where agents learn to mimic
> =
exact behaviors. Humans fortunately function at a higher level, imitation,
=
> because we can observe a behavior and then acquire new skills or talents =
by
> combining it with other knowledge or experiences we've previously acqu=
ired,
> resulting in an entirely new behavior. So from my perspective, soci=
al
> learning among humans is one not a threat to novelty, but rather one o=
f the
> greatest sources of it.
> 
> Sincerely,
> Wesley
> 
> On Thu, Apr 1=
9, 2012 at 6:48 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >=
 Hi Wesley, congrats on the GECCO paper and also thanks for sharing the
> >=
 software. I do have a couple questions/comments:
> >
> > The subculture id=
ea is interesting but did you consider aligning the
> > subcultures with th=
e NEAT-determined species divisions? It seems strange
> > that a "subcultur=
e" could cut across species, though I suppose the
> > existence of dogs and=
 cats in human households is sort of analogous. On the
> > other hand when =
you can actually "learn" to be almost identical to another
> > species (as =
you can when you are just a neural network) maybe it doesn't
> > really mat=
ter that much what species you started from.
> >
> > On a more philosophica=
l level, it's interesting that teaching in general
> > is a kind of converg=
ent force towards conformity. Obviously some of that is
> > necessary in so=
ciety, but it raises the question of whether societies
> > transmit creativ=
ity through teaching (or at least can avoid damaging
> > creativity when te=
aching). This question is a bit abstract, but it does
> > relate to novelty=
 search - the kind of divergent proliferation of stepping
> > stones seen i=
n non-objective search is potentially inhibited in a social
> > learning so=
ciety. So it raises the question of whether you can actually
> > have both =
social transmission and non-objective divergence together.
> > Interestingl=
y, human society seems to have both ingredients working very
> > effectivel=
y together.
> >
> > ken
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tan=
sey <tansey@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi all,
> > >
> > > I'm proud to announce =
my first GECCO paper!
> > >
> > > Title: Accelerating Evolution via Egalita=
rian Social Learning
> > > Authors: Wesley Tansey, Eliana Feasley, and Rist=
o Miikkulainen
> > >
> > > Abstract:
> > > Social learning is an extension =
to evolutionary algorithms that enables
> > > agents to learn from observat=
ions of others in the population.
> > > Historically, social learning algor=
ithms have employed a student-teacher
> > > model where the behavior of one=
 or more high-fitness agents is used to
> > > train a subset of the remaini=
ng agents in the population. This paper
> > > presents ESL, an egalitarian =
model of social learning in which agents are
> > > not labeled as teachers =
or students, instead allowing any individual
> > > receiving a sufficiently=
 high reward to teach other agents to mimic its
> > > recent behavior. We v=
alidate our approach through a series of experiments
> > > in a robot forag=
ing domain, including comparisons of egalitarian social
> > > learning with=
 baseline neuroevolution and a variant of student-teacher
> > > social lear=
ning. In a complex foraging task, ESL converges to
> > near-optimal
> > > s=
trategies faster than either benchmark approach, outperforming both by
> > =
> more than an order of magnitude. The results indicate that egalitarian
> =
> > social learning is a promising new paradigm for social learning in
> > =
> intelligent agents.
> > >
> > > Paper page: http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-v=
iew.php?PubID=3D127157
> > >
> > > Github repository for all source code:
>=
 > > https://github.com/tansey/social-learning
> > >
> > > A couple of thin=
gs to note here that I believe will be very helpful to
> > > anyone using S=
harpNEAT in general:
> > >
> > > - If you're looking to do Lamarckian evolu=
tion, it turns out to be very
> > > easy: https://gist.github.com/2410490
>=
 > >
> > > - We implemented backpropagation through time for the FastCyclic=
Network.
> > > Using the SharpNeatV2 that is in the github repo, you can pe=
rform
> > > supervised learning on a NEAT network very easily, enabling onl=
ine
> > learning
> > > algorithms to be incorporated into SharpNEAT experim=
ents:
> > > https://gist.github.com/2410545
> > >
> > > Colin, I'd love if =
you could take a look at the backprop implementation
> > and
> > > potentia=
lly integrate it into a future release of SharpNEAT. Outside of
> > our
> >=
 > hacking of the FastCyclicNetwork class, it only required changing
> > > =
permissions on a few properties here and there.
> > >
> > > The caveats her=
e are that the backprop implementation requires you reset
> > > the network=
 state at every activation to be correct. If you're doing
> > > something w=
here recurrent networks that maintain state between calls are
> > > require=
d, then the performance of this method is not guaranteed to work.
> > >
> >=
 > If anyone has any comments or questions on the paper, I'm happy to
> > d=
iscuss
> > > it!
> > >
> > > Sincerely,
> > > Wesley
> > >
> >
> >  
> >
>
